questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravida patient is in labour at 42 weeks of POG. P/V examination findings are – os fully dilated, 70% effaced, membranes ruptured, the pelvis is adequate, and the fetal head station is +2. The uterine contractions are adequate at a rate of 3/10 min for 30 sec. After 45 minutes of full dilatation, now the mother is exhausted. The fetal heart rate was 100, with no beat-to-beat variability. She is a known case of grade 2 NYHA heart failure. Hence she was delivered with the help of a forceps application. Which of the following is not an indication of forceps delivery in the above question?

options.label: D
options.text: Known case of grade 2 NYHA heart failure

questions.explanation:
Solution:

45 minutes after full dilatation According to the given scenario, a prolonged second stage of labour (nullipara>2 hours, multipara >1 hour) is the indication and not 45 minutes. Hence it is incorrect.

Highyeild:

Criteria for forceps delivery: Favourable position and station. OS fully dilated. The cervix is fully dilated. Membranes ruptured. The head of the baby rotated. Uterus contracting. Episiotomy given. Head engaged. Bladder empty. Adequate pelvis. No CPD.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A . Non-reassuring fetal heart rate, fetal distress eg: low birth weight, postmaturity. Option B. Maternal effects like maternal exhaustion, and inadequate expulsion efforts, where expulsive efforts are to be avoided cardiac disease, hypertensive crises, cerebrovascular diseases, and spinal cord injuries. Option D. Known cases of grade 2 NYHA heart failure are an important indication to cut short the second stage of labour. Another indication can be preeclampsia, post caesarean pregnancy.

Extraedge:

Maximum traction in primi is 20 kgs and in multi is 13 kgs, applied along occipitomental diameter.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old primigravida female in labour is set to undergo vaginal delivery with the help of a vacuum application. What should be the sequence in the application of vacuum for delivery? The cup is introduced after retraction of the perineum with two fingers of the other hand. Pudendal block or perineal infiltration with 1% lignocaine. Traction over this flexion point by ventouse synchronous with the uterine contractions. The cup is placed against the fetal head nearer the occiput (flexion point) with the “knob” of the cup pointing towards the occiput. The fingers of the other hand are to be placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation and advancement of the head. As soon as the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve and the cup is then detached . Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BADCEF

Highyeild:

The correct sequence for delivery via ventouse application is: Pudendal block or perineal infiltration with 1% lignocaine. The cup is introduced after retraction of the perineum with two fingers of the other hand. The cup is placed against the fetal head nearer the occiput (flexion point) with the “knob” of the cup pointing towards the occiput. Traction over this flexion point by ventouse synchronous with the uterine contractions. The fingers of the other hand are to be placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation and advancement of the head. As soon as the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve and the cup is then detached.

Extraedge:

In heart disease, a vacuum is preferred as a lithotomy position is not necessary.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding forceps and vacuum delivery except:

options.label: A
options.text: Vacuum requires more clinical skills than forceps

options.label: B
options.text: Vacuum is preferred more in HIV patients than forceps

options.label: C
options.text: Forceps are more associated with fetal facial injury

options.label: D
options.text: Vacuum has more chance of formation of cephalhematoma

questions.correct_answer: A. Vacuum requires more clinical skills than forceps
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vacuum requires more clinical skills than forceps Forceps require more skills than vacuums. Options B, C & D are true.

Highyeild:

Forceps can be used in preterm delivery. Can be used in all those presentations where vaginal delivery is possible and if fetal distress is present. Ventouse is comfortable and has lower rates of maternal trauma and genital tract lacerations. Reduced maternal pelvic floor injuries. Perineal injuries are less. Vacuum is preferred more than forceps in HIV patients to decrease mother-to-child transmission.

Extraedge:

In heart disease, a vacuum is preferred as a lithotomy position is not necessary.

questions.text: In heart disease, prophylactic forceps are applied at the head station of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

+2 In heart disease forceps are applied prophylactically to cut down the second stage of labour and usually low or outlet forceps are applied.

Highyeild:

Low forceps: Applied when the leading point of the fetal scalp is at station + 2 and not on the pelvic floor. Outlet forceps: Applied, when the fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor and the scalp, is visible at the introitus even without separating the labia, i.e. station ≥ + 3

Extraedge:

In heart disease, a vacuum is preferred as a lithotomy position is not necessary.

questions.text: You are attending a workshop on forceps delivery for females, its indications, prerequisites, and sequential steps involved below image shows the steps of low forceps operation. Which of the following depicts the correct sequence of forceps application? (A). Introduction of the right blade (B). The handle lying flat on the perineum after the introduction (C). Introduction of the left blade (D). Change in the grip in the final stage of delivery (E). Bimalar, biparietal placement of blades and position of the fingers during traction (F). Showing perfect apposition and locking of the blades Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CBAFED The correct sequence of low forceps operation will be: (C) Introduction of the left blade (B) The handle lying flat on the perineum after the introduction (A) Introduction of the right blade (F) Showing perfect apposition and locking of the blades (E) Bimalar, biparietal placement of blades and position of the fingers during traction (D) Change in the grip in the final stage of delivery

questions.text: You are posted in the labour room for your internship rotation. You observe four females in labor out of which one of them requires forceps extraction. Which of the following fulfils the prerequisites for forceps delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: A 22-year-old primigravida patient with membranes intact, and adequate uterine contractions.

options.label: B
options.text: 24-year-old primigravida with cervix 5 cm dilated, 60% effaced, uterine contractions 3/10 min for 20 sec.

options.label: C
options.text: 30-year-old G2P1 female with membranes ruptured, cervix fully dilated, station of the head +3.

options.label: D
options.text: A G2P1 female with a previous history for C- section due to cephalopelvic disproportion.

questions.correct_answer: C. 30-year-old G2P1 female with membranes ruptured, cervix fully dilated, station of the head +3.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30-year-old G2P1 female with membranes ruptured, cervix fully dilated, station of the head +3.

Highyeild:

Important prerequisites will be: Fetal head engaged (head ≤ 1/5 palpable per abdomen) The cervix must be fully dilated The membranes must be ruptured The fetal head position is exactly known Pelvis deemed adequate

Extraedge:

C/I for instrumental delivery : Mother HIV positive Fetus: Known coagulopathy Osteogenesis Imperfecta Pelvis contracted/CPD
